description: Science-backed strength training knowledge base for AI fitness coach

muscle_group_recovery.description: Muscle groups need 48-72 hours of recovery between training sessions for optimal adaptation
muscle_group_recovery.reasoning: Individual recovery capacity varies hugely based on genetics, experience, volume, nutrition, sleep, and stress. This is a guideline, not a law.
sources: Schoenfeld et al. (2016). Effects of Resistance Training Frequency on Measures of Muscle Hypertrophy
Grgic et al. (2018). The effects of resistance training frequency on muscle hypertrophy
muscle_group_recovery.notes: Smaller muscle groups (biceps, triceps) may recover faster. Larger muscle groups (legs, back) may need closer to 72 hours. Individual variation is huge - adjust based on your response.

full_body_recovery.description: Full body workouts should have at least 24-48 hours between sessions
sources: Schoenfeld et al. (2016). Effects of Resistance Training Frequency

weight_increase.description: Gradual increase in weight to stimulate adaptation
weight_increase.reasoning: Progressive overload is well-established, but the exact rate varies hugely by individual, training age, and goals.
sources: Kraemer & Ratamess (2004). Fundamentals of resistance training
ACSM Position Stand (2009). Progression models in resistance training
weight_increase.notes: Increase weight when you can complete all sets with 1-2 reps in reserve. Beginners may progress faster, advanced lifters much slower. Plateaus are normal.

volume_increase.method: Add 1-2 sets per exercise or 1-2 reps per set
volume_increase.description: Can increase volume (sets x reps) instead of or in addition to weight
sources: Schoenfeld et al. (2017). Dose-response relationship between weekly resistance training volume and increases in muscle mass

frequency_increase.method: Add training sessions per week for same muscle group
frequency_increase.optimal: 2-3 times per week per muscle group
frequency_increase.description: Increasing training frequency can improve results
sources: Schoenfeld et al. (2016). Effects of Resistance Training Frequency

sets_per_muscle_group.description: Total sets per muscle group per week for optimal hypertrophy
sets_per_muscle_group.reasoning: More volume generally = more growth, but optimal volume varies hugely by individual, training age, and recovery capacity.
sources: Schoenfeld et al. (2017). Dose-response relationship between weekly resistance training volume
Krieger (2010). Single vs. multiple sets of resistance exercise
sets_per_muscle_group.notes: Volume should be distributed across 2-3 sessions per week. This is a guideline - adjust based on your recovery and progress. Individual variation is huge.

reps_per_set.description: Rep ranges for different training goals
sources: Schoenfeld (2010). The mechanisms of muscle hypertrophy
ACSM Position Stand (2009). Progression models in resistance training
reps_per_set.notes: Most people training for general fitness should focus on 6-12 reps for hypertrophy

sources: Schoenfeld et al. (2016). Effects of rest interval length on training adaptations

per_muscle_group.reasoning: 2-3x per week seems optimal for most, but some do well with 1x/week, others with 4-5x/week (with lower volume per session). Individual variation is huge.
sources: Schoenfeld et al. (2016). Effects of Resistance Training Frequency
Grgic et al. (2018). The effects of resistance training frequency
per_muscle_group.notes: Beginners can see results with 2x/week. Intermediate/advanced may benefit from 3x/week. This is a guideline - adjust based on your recovery and progress.

full_body.description: Train all major muscle groups each session

upper_lower.description: Alternate between upper and lower body

core.notes: Core can be trained more frequently, often worked indirectly

compound_movements.description: Multi-joint exercises should form the foundation
compound_movements.reasoning: Well-established principle - compound movements are efficient and effective. This is a strong recommendation.
sources: ACSM Position Stand (2009). Progression models in resistance training

isolation_movements.description: Single-joint exercises for specific muscle groups
isolation_movements.notes: Should complement, not replace, compound movements

main_workout.description: Prioritize heavy, complex movements when fresh

specificity.description: Training should be specific to your goals
specificity.application: If goal is strength, train in 1-5 rep range. If hypertrophy, 6-12 reps.

overload.description: Must progressively challenge the body to adapt
overload.application: Increase weight, volume, or frequency over time

variation.application: Change exercises, rep ranges, or training methods every 4-8 weeks
sources: Kraemer & Ratamess (2004). Fundamentals of resistance training

individualization.description: Training should be tailored to individual needs, experience, and recovery capacity
individualization.application: Adjust volume, frequency, and intensity based on individual response

overtraining.prevention: Ensure adequate recovery (48-72 hours between muscle groups)

insufficient_progression.prevention: Track workouts and increase weight/volume systematically

poor_exercise_selection.description: Too much isolation, not enough compound movements
poor_exercise_selection.prevention: Prioritize compound movements, use isolation as supplement

inadequate_recovery.description: Training same muscle groups too frequently

strategies: Deload week (reduce volume by 50% for 1 week)
sources: Kraemer & Ratamess (2004). Fundamentals of resistance training

primary_sources: Schoenfeld, B. J., et al. (2016). Effects of Resistance Training Frequency on Measures of Muscle Hypertrophy: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis. Sports Medicine, 46(11), 1689-1697.

Schoenfeld, B. J., et al. (2017). Dose-response relationship between weekly resistance training volume and increases in muscle mass: A systematic review and meta-analysis. Journal of Sports Sciences, 35(11), 1073-1082.
ACSM Position Stand (2009). Progression models in resistance training for healthy adults. Medicine & Science in Sports & Exercise, 41(3), 687-708.
Kraemer, W. J., & Ratamess, N. A. (2004). Fundamentals of resistance training: progression and exercise prescription. Medicine & Science in Sports & Exercise, 36(4), 674-688.
Schoenfeld, B. J. (2010). The mechanisms of muscle hypertrophy and their application to resistance training. Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research, 24(10), 2857-2872.
Grgic, J., et al. (2018). The effects of resistance training frequency on muscle hypertrophy: A systematic review and meta-analysis. Sports Medicine, 48(5), 1207-1240.
Krieger, J. W. (2010). Single vs. multiple sets of resistance exercise for muscle hypertrophy: A meta-analysis. Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research, 24(4), 1150-1159.
citations.notes: This knowledge base is based on peer-reviewed research in exercise science. Recommendations are evidence-based but should be adapted to individual needs.
